qas.question: What schools can trace their origins back

answers.text: Several schools can trace their origins back many years, such as The Blue School in Wells and Richard Huish College in Taunton

qas.question: What was the original name of the Beechen Cliff School

answers.text: started in 1905 as the City of Bath Boys' School

qas.question: In 2006 Somerset students performed how well compared to England as a whole

answers.text: In 2006, 5,900 pupils in Somerset sat GCSE examinations, with 44.5% achieving 5 grades A-C including English and Maths (compared to 45.8% for England).

qas.question: In what year was The Blue School established?
In what year did Richard Huish College open its doors?
At The Blue School what is the percentage of students achieve 5 grades A-C?
What 5 grades A-C percentage to they get at City of Bath Boys' School?
How many students attend the Richard Huish College?

context: Some of the county's secondary schools have specialist school status. Some schools have sixth forms and others transfer their sixth formers to colleges. <a0_0>Several schools can trace their origins back many years, such as The Blue School in Wells and Richard Huish College in Taunton<a0_0/>. Others have changed their names over the years such as Beechen Cliff School which was <a1_0>started in <b3_0>1905<b3_0/> as the City of Bath Boys' School<a1_0/> and changed to its present name in <b4_0>1972<b4_0/> when the grammar school was amalgamated with a local secondary modern school, to form a comprehensive school. Many others were established and built since the Second World War. <a2_0>In 2006, <b7_0>5,900<b7_0/> pupils in Somerset sat GCSE examinations, with <b6_0>44.5%<b6_0/> achieving 5 grades A-C including English and Maths (compared to <b5_0>45.8%<b5_0/> for England).
